name: Celina Cabo
title: Housekeeping Manager
location: Scottsdale, AZ is already on the list. Let me provide the next best option:\n\nMaui, HI

flow.context: Celina Cabo is Housekeeping Manager at Coldwell Banker Island Vacations — she owns the cleaner workflow and photo documentation across 300+ properties on Maui, Kauai, and Big Island. CBIV has operated since 2001 with on-island teams; no known inspection tech platform, so turnover QC is likely manual. Above her: Justin Simpson (Ops Manager, direct line 808-909-3103) and Amanda Franta (GM/Founder, amanda@cbislandvacations.com). Calling the main office line 808-891-2900, so you may hit a gatekeeper — ask for Celina by name. Sam's surfing background and work with similar Hawaii PM operations are the natural entry point.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Celina — this is Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few other vacation rental teams out in Hawaii on their turnover inspection stuff, and your name came up as the person running housekeeping over at CB Island Vacations. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Smile. Relaxed. Feet up on the desk energy. Don't rush through it — sound like you belong in this conversation. If someone else answers, go to gatekeeper.

branches.label: No / Who? / I haven't heard of you
Yes / Maybe / Sounds familiar
I'm busy / bad timing
Someone else answers the phone

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF ME
heard_name_no.say: Ha — well I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I've been talking to a few other housekeeping leads at companies pretty similar to yours, and they keep bringing up the same thing...
heard_name_no.note: Laugh it off naturally. This transitions straight into the pain trigger. Don't pause too long here — keep the momentum going.

branches.label: Okay... / listening
I'm not interested
What do you mean?

heard_name_yes.label: HEARD THE NAME
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone exactly in your seat. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge to pain trigger or discovery. Don't correct anything — just listen and flow.

branches.label: Don't remember / not much
Something about inspections / photos / AI
Someone mentioned you / vague

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — I know you've probably got turnovers stacking up. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe first thing before the day gets crazy?
bad_timing.note: Respect the timing. Lock in a callback window. Don't pitch. If she gives you an opening, take it.

branches.label: Sure, try me tomorrow / gives a time
Just tell me quick
Don't call back

bad_timing_callback.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
bad_timing_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try you in the morning. Appreciate it, Celina.
bad_timing_callback.note: Done. Don't push further. Call back exactly when you said you would. Add a calendar reminder now.

gatekeeper_slide.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_slide.say: Hey — could you get me through to Celina? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_slide.note: Casual. First name only. Don't explain why. Don't volunteer information. You ask the questions.

branches.label: Who's calling? / What's this about?
Let me transfer you / hold on
She's not available

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property management teams out in Hawaii. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still casual. Give just enough. Don't pitch the gatekeeper. Redirect with a question.

branches.label: Let me check / transferring
She's busy / what company?
Can I take a message?

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally get it — we help a couple other vacation rental companies with their inspection workflows. I sent her a note already, just wanted to follow up real quick. Would you mind giving her a heads up that Sam Parks called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If this doesn't work, leave a message and move on. Don't get adversarial with the gatekeeper.

branches.label: I'll let her know / taking a message
Transferring you

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: GATEKEEPER — GET INFO
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: Appreciate that. If she's got a direct line or a good time to catch her, that'd be super helpful. Otherwise I'll try her again.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Try to get a direct number or best callback time. Write down whatever they give you. Then either leave a voicemail or hang up and retry.

branches.label: Gives direct number or callback time
No additional info / sending to voicemail

end_gatekeeper_info.label: GOT GATEKEEPER INFO
end_gatekeeper_info.say: That's awesome, thank you so much. I'll reach out then.
end_gatekeeper_info.note: Write down the number or time immediately. Call at the suggested time. This is a win — treat it like one.

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Celina — it's Sam Parks. I work with a few vacation rental teams out in Hawaii on their turnover inspection workflows. Wanted to run something by you real quick — I'll try you again tomorrow. Or if it's easier, you can grab me at [your number]. Talk soon.
voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. No pitch. Create curiosity. Call back tomorrow regardless of whether she calls back. Try at a different time of day.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another housekeeping manager — actually runs a team about your size, three hundred-plus units across a couple islands — and she was telling me her cleaners are taking a hundred-plus photos every single turnover, which is great, but nobody actually has time to review them all. So stuff slips through — a stain on a couch, a missing coffee maker, a screen door that's off track — and it doesn't get caught until the next guest checks in and leaves a one-star review. And then it's her problem. Sound familiar at all?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'sound familiar.' Count to three in your head. Let her react. Don't fill the silence. This is where you find out if the pain is real. The specifics — stain, coffee maker, screen door — are what make this land.

branches.label: Yeah, that's exactly what happens / totally
We actually do a pretty good job with that
Not really / we don't do it that way
Who is this? / What is this about?

pivot_curiosity.label: PIVOT — LEARN THEIR PROCESS
pivot_curiosity.say: Oh interesting — how are you guys handling the post-clean verification right now? I'm always curious because everyone does it a little differently.
pivot_curiosity.note: Genuine curiosity. Shut up and listen. You might find a different angle into the pain, or learn they're more manual than expected.

branches.label: Describes their process
We don't really have an issue
I don't have time for this

solution_cta.label: SOLUTION + CTA
solution_cta.say: Yeah — so that's exactly why we built RapidEye. It plugs into whatever your cleaners are already using to take photos and automatically flags anything that's off — damage, missing stuff, staging issues — so your team doesn't have to eyeball every single photo. Would you be open to seeing what it looks like? I promise I won't waste your time.
solution_cta.note: One sentence on the product. One sentence CTA. Don't oversell. Don't list features. If she says yes, go straight to booking. Don't keep pitching.

branches.label: Sure / yeah I'd look at that
Send me something first
I'd need to talk to Justin or Amanda
We don't have budget
I'm not sure I'm the right person

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out, and if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me?
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. Most people will give you 30 seconds if you ask directly and give them an out.

branches.label: Okay, go ahead / make it quick
No, I'm not interested

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad for interrupting your day. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is this just not something you're focused on right now?
permission_rejected.note: This isn't giving up — it's splitting the objection. Often they'll reveal the real reason and re-engage.

branches.label: Bad timing / caught me at a bad time
Not focused on this / not interested
Actually... what is it exactly?

permission_rejected_timing.label: RESCUE — BAD TIMING
permission_rejected_timing.say: Totally get it. When would be a less terrible time to try you? I can work around your schedule.
permission_rejected_timing.note: Get a specific day or time window. Even a vague 'try me Thursday' is a win.

branches.label: Gives a time / try me tomorrow
Don't call back

warm_discovery.label: DISCOVERY — THEIR PROCESS
warm_discovery.say: Oh that's really helpful. So walk me through it — when a cleaner finishes a unit, what does the process look like from there? Do they upload photos somewhere, does someone review them, or is it more of a spot-check situation?
warm_discovery.note: SHUT UP AND LISTEN. Take notes. You're learning their workflow to tailor the pitch. Don't interrupt. Don't jump to your product.

branches.label: Describes process in detail
We use a specific tool or system
It's kind of a mess honestly

discovery_tech.label: DISCOVERY — TECH STACK
discovery_tech.say: Oh got it — and is that handling the actual photo review for you, or is it more for task management and scheduling? I ask because a lot of teams I talk to have great tools for assigning the work but nothing that actually looks at what's in the photos.
discovery_tech.note: Distinguish between task management tools (Breezeway, Track, etc.) and actual photo analysis. That gap is RapidEye's lane. If they name a tool, note it for later.

branches.label: It's more task management / scheduling
It does everything we need
We don't really use anything fancy

discovery_deeper.label: DISCOVERY — COST OF MISSES
discovery_deeper.say: And when something does get missed — like a broken drawer or a stain that wasn't there before — how does that usually surface? Is it the next guest complaining, or does your team catch it on a re-inspect?
discovery_deeper.note: You're looking for the cost of misses: guest complaints, owner calls, review damage, re-cleans, deposit disputes. This is where the pain gets personal for her.

branches.label: Usually the guest catches it
We do re-inspects / we catch most things
It depends / varies

discovery_cost_of_miss.label: DISCOVERY — ACCOUNTABILITY
discovery_cost_of_miss.say: And when that happens — guest finds something, leaves a review — does that come back on you and the housekeeping team, or does that land more on Justin and the ops side?
discovery_cost_of_miss.note: You're mapping the accountability chain. This also plants the seed that you know their org, which builds credibility. If it lands on her, the pain is personal. If it lands on ops, you have a referral angle.

branches.label: It comes back on me / housekeeping
That's more of an ops thing / Justin handles it
We all deal with it together

discovery_pain_confirmed.label: BRIDGE TO CTA
discovery_pain_confirmed.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I keep hearing. And with three hundred-plus units across multiple islands, I imagine it's not like you can personally walk every property. That's actually the exact problem we built RapidEye to solve. Would you be open to seeing what it looks like? Fifteen minutes, super casual.
discovery_pain_confirmed.note: Bridge from their pain to the CTA. Keep it conversational, not pitchy. If she says yes, book it immediately.

branches.label: Sure / yeah let's do it
I'd need to run it by someone
Send me info first
I don't think we have budget

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've figured you'd have everything dialed in already, otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're dealing with, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because honestly, I get it either way.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Then split. Most people soften when you validate them instead of pushing back. The 'hate cold calls' option usually gets a laugh.

branches.label: I just don't like cold calls / laughs
We're really not having that problem
Actually we do deal with that but...
Just not interested / firm no

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with three hundred properties across three islands, you'd have to have something solid in place. Just out of curiosity — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a pain with everything else going on?
objection_have_process.note: Validate their process. Then split. 'Everything else going on' nods to Bill 9 regulatory pressure and operational complexity without being too direct. Let her tell you what 'everything else' means to her.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching would be a headache
It works but it's not perfect
What do you mean everything else?

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's hard enough to keep the tools you've got, let alone bring on something new. Especially with everything shifting in the Maui market right now. Is it that budget this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new would need to go through Amanda and the whole approval process?
objection_no_budget.note: Validate budget concern. Reference Maui market pressure (Bill 9 phase-out) to show you understand their world. Name-dropping Amanda shows homework and opens the referral path naturally.

branches.label: Budget is locked / we're tight
It would need Amanda's approval / need to go up
It's both honestly
How do you know Amanda?

credibility_response.label: CREDIBILITY CHECK
credibility_response.say: Oh — I've just been doing a bunch of research on your team before reaching out. Didn't want to be one of those people who calls without knowing who they're talking to. But that's actually why I wanted to start with you — you're the one who lives this every day on the housekeeping side.
credibility_response.note: Be honest about the research. It builds trust. Then redirect back to the conversation. This is a compliment — she's the expert, not just a stepping stone.

branches.label: Fair enough / appreciates the research
What exactly do you do?

bill_9_angle.label: BILL 9 / MARKET PRESSURE
bill_9_angle.say: Yeah — I mean with Bill 9 and the phase-out timelines, a lot of the managers I've been talking to on Maui are trying to figure out how to do more with less. Tighter margins, fewer units potentially, more pressure to protect the ones you've got. That's actually a big part of why we're reaching out now — the companies getting ahead of this are locking in their inspection quality so they can protect owner relationships and reviews even as things shift. Does that resonate at all?
bill_9_angle.note: Don't oversell the regulatory angle — some people are stressed about Bill 9, others aren't worried yet. Let her tell you where she stands. If she says it's above her pay grade, that's a natural referral to Amanda or Justin.

branches.label: Yeah, that's definitely on our minds
We're not too worried about that
That's above my pay grade / more of an Amanda thing

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything on a cold call, and I totally respect that. But when budget does open up or the timing's right, the teams that move fastest are the ones who already know what's out there. Would you be open to just taking a look — fifteen minutes, super casual — not to sell you anything today, but just so you know what we do? Worst case, I walk you through what other Hawaii PM companies are doing with their turnover photos and you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: Low pressure. Position the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. The 'steal some ideas' line usually lands well and reframes the meeting as peer-to-peer.

branches.label: Okay sure / I could do that
Send me an email first
I'm really not the right person for this
No thanks / not right now

sell_test_drive_light.label: SOFT TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive_light.say: Totally fair. And honestly, if you've got it covered, that's great — I'm not trying to fix something that isn't broken. But would it be worth fifteen minutes just to compare notes? I can show you what a couple other companies your size are doing differently — and if your process is better, tell me and I'll steal your ideas instead.
sell_test_drive_light.note: Light touch. The ego play works well — telling her she might be doing it better than others is disarming and genuine.

branches.label: Sure, that could work
Send me something first
No, I'm good

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally get it — and honestly I appreciate you telling me that instead of just sitting through a call that's not relevant. Who on your team would typically make the call on something like inspection tooling? Would that be more Justin's world, or does that go straight to Amanda?
not_right_person.note: Name the people you know. It shows preparation and makes the referral feel natural. Give her two options — both of which you've researched.

branches.label: Talk to Justin / ops would handle that
Talk to Amanda / it'd go to the top
I'm not sure who handles that
Actually it might be me, tell me more

referral_path_up.label: REFERRAL PATH UP
referral_path_up.say: That makes total sense — I figured something like this would need a thumbs-up from higher up. Would it make more sense for me to reach out to Justin on the ops side, or would Amanda be the better starting point? I want to put something tailored together so it actually lands when they see it.
referral_path_up.note: Give her two options. Both are researched. Makes it easy for her to direct you. If she offers to bring it up internally, that's the best outcome — warm intro.

branches.label: Try Justin / he handles ops tools
Try Amanda / she makes those calls
Let me bring it up internally first
Actually I can make this call / let me see it

referral_get_name_justin.label: REFERRAL — JUSTIN
referral_get_name_justin.say: Perfect — Justin Simpson, right? Operations Manager? Do you know if he's got a good time to catch him, or should I just try his direct line?
referral_get_name_justin.note: Confirm what you already know. You have Justin's direct line (808-909-3103) but getting Celina to point you there makes it a warm intro. Ask if you can mention her name.

branches.label: Gives info or confirms / yes that's him
Just try the office / not sure

referral_get_name_amanda.label: REFERRAL — AMANDA
referral_get_name_amanda.say: Perfect — Amanda Franta? Do you happen to know the best way to reach her — is she more of an email person or phone person?
referral_get_name_amanda.note: You already have amanda@cbislandvacations.com but getting Celina to validate the channel and potentially intro you is gold. Ask if you can mention Celina pointed you her way.

branches.label: Gives info / email her / call the office
Just try her

referral_ask_general.label: REFERRAL — GENERAL ASK
referral_ask_general.say: No worries — who on your team would you say owns the inspection workflow from a decision-making standpoint? Like if you were going to bring a new tool to someone and say hey we should try this, who would that go to?
referral_ask_general.note: Let her think. Don't rush. You're mapping the org. Any name she gives you is valuable.

branches.label: Gives a name
I'm not sure / let me find out

referral_internal.label: INTERNAL CHAMPION PATH
referral_internal.say: That'd be amazing — if you could float it internally and I follow up in a couple days, that'd be perfect. Would it be cool if I sent you a quick email you could forward? Something super short — just so they have context when my name comes up.
referral_internal.note: Give her something easy to forward. Don't make her do the selling for you. The email should be short, specific, and forward-friendly. Email likely: celina@cbislandvacations.com based on the firstname@ pattern from Amanda's confirmed email.

branches.label: Sure, send it over
I'll just mention it verbally

referral_end.label: REFERRAL WRAP-UP
referral_end.say: Really appreciate that, Celina. I'll reach out to them and mention you pointed me their way — won't make it weird, I promise. Thanks for your time.
referral_end.note: Keep it warm. She just gave you a referral — that's a win. Don't overstay. Call the referred person within 24 hours and lead with Celina's name.

booking.label: BOOK THE MEETING
booking.say: Awesome — let me grab a time real quick. I've got next Tuesday or Thursday open — what works better for you, morning or afternoon your time?
booking.note: Give two days as options. Don't say 'when works for you' — too open-ended. Anchor to specific days. Remember she's on Hawaii time (HST).

branches.label: Picks a day and time
Let me check my calendar / not sure

booking_soft.label: SOFT BOOK
booking_soft.say: No rush — how about I send you an invite for Thursday at ten your time, and if it doesn't work you just let me know and we'll move it? That way it's on the calendar and we don't have to play phone tag.
booking_soft.note: Anchor a specific time. It's easier to move a meeting than to schedule one from scratch. Send the invite immediately after hanging up.

branches.label: Sure, that works / send it
Just email me first

booking_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED
booking_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll send that invite right now so it's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Celina. Talk to you then.
booking_confirmed.note: Send the calendar invite IMMEDIATELY while it's fresh. Then STOP TALKING. Don't keep selling. You won. Include a brief agenda in the invite: 'Quick 15-min look at how RapidEye works with turnover photos — no pressure.'

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox — what would be most useful for me to include? Like would you want to see how it actually works with turnover photos, or more of a quick overview of what other companies your size are doing?
send_email.note: Tailor the email based on her answer. Her email is likely celina@cbislandvacations.com (firstname@ pattern confirmed from Amanda's). Include a specific time suggestion in the email. Send within the hour.

branches.label: Show me how it works / the product
Just send whatever / keep it short
What other companies are doing

send_email_end.label: EMAIL WRAP-UP
send_email_end.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. And I'll throw a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've had a chance to look. Thanks for your time, Celina.
send_email_end.note: Send it within one hour. Reference this conversation specifically so she knows it's not a template. Include two specific time slots. Follow up in 3 days if no response. Email: celina@cbislandvacations.com.

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Celina.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn bridges. Stay warm. Add her to a 30-day follow-up. Consider reaching out to Justin Simpson (Ops Manager) or Amanda Franta (GM) directly as your next move on this account.
